media_caption: Marcelo H. del Pilar, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Marcelo H. del Pilar and friends publish Dasalan at Tocsohan, an antifriar parody of Catholic prayers and the catechism. (Photo from CCP Collection)

media_caption: Graciano Lopez Jaena, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: "Fray Botod" by Graciano Lopez Jaena (in photo), an anticlerical satire, appears in Discursos y Articulos Varios in Barcelona.

media_caption: Pinaglahuan by Faustino Aguilar, 1907, Pre-World War II novels written in local languages
media_credit: Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection and University of the Philippines Press
text_description: The novel Pinaglahuan by Faustino Aguilar, which depicts the entry of American capitalism and forwards a radical structural change to transform society, is published. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Title page of Salvador P. Lopez’s Literature and Society, 1940, which defines writing as social commitment
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
text_description: Literature and Society by Salvador P. Lopez, which advocates “proletarian literature,” is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, 1982, National Artists for Literature
article_title: Lit 1941.2 I Am a Filipino by Romulo
text_description: Aug: Carlos P. Romulo’s speech “I Am a Filipino” is published in The Philippines Herald. It will be a familiar oratorical piece in Philippine high schools.

media_caption: America is in the Heart by Carlos Bulosan, Carlos Bulosan’s poetry and fiction about the Filipino experience in the Philippines and the United States
media_credit: Photo from University of Washington Press and Coward-McCann
article_title: Lit 1946 America is in the Heart
text_description: America Is in the Heart by Carlos Bulosan is published in New York. In narrating the experiences of Filipino laborers in the United States, it will become a key text in Philippine-American and Asian American literature. (Photo from University of Washington Press and Coward-McCann)

media_caption: Without Seeing the Dawn, Steven Javellana, 1998 reprint, Philippine novels in English
text_description: Without Seeing the Dawn by Stevan Javellana, considered the most artistic and compelling narrative of the Filipino experience of World War II, is published in Boston. Photo: Book cover of 1998 reprint (Photo from Phoenix Press)

media_caption: SIGWA, Book covers courtesy of University of the Philippines Press
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Sigwa, containing Tagalog short stories by young and veteran writers who are involved in the political protest movement of the 1970s, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Dekada '70 by Lualhati Bautista, 1988, Social realist literature
text_description: Lualhati Bautista’s martial law novel Dekada ’70, also known for one of the earliest articulations of feminism in contemporary Philippine literature, is published. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Lilia Quindoza Santiago, Reuel Molina Aguila, Herminio S. Beltran, Jr., Anthologies of activist literature during the martial law era
text_description: The first of a series of anthologies (poetry, short story, drama) of the literature of protest in the Philippines, Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Tula), is published by the CCP.

media_caption: Kapampangan,Translations of the Tagalog Pasyong Genesis
text_description: The Pasyong Genesis or Casaysayan nang Mahal na Pasion, aka Pasyong Pilapil, after Mariano Pilapil, the censor who approved it, is published. It is the second and most popular of the Tagalog pasyon, credited for shaping the Christian Filipinos’ image of Jesus Christ. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

media_caption: A 1939 film adaptation of Florante at Laura, directed by Vicente Salumbides
text_description: Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas writes and publishes Florante at Laura, the most famous awit in Philippine literary history. It is interpreted by many as the first example of protest literature in the Philippines. Photo: A 1939 film adaptation of Florante at Laura, directed by Vicente Salumbides (James dela Rosa/Pelikula, Atbp.)

media_caption: American period reprint of Urbana at Feliza, first published in 1864
media_credit: Photo from National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Urbana at Feliza by Modesto de Castro, a slim conduct book considered a precursor of the Tagalog novel, is published. Photo: American period reprint (National Library of the Philippines Collection)

media_caption: Ninay by Pedro Paterno(novel), Cover of the Manila edition of Pedro Paterno’s novel
media_credit: Photo from University of Michigan and CCP Collection
text_description: The first Filipino novel, Ninay: Costumbres Filipinas by Pedro Paterno, is published in Madrid. (Photo from University of Michigan)

media_caption: Cover of Fray Miguel Lucio y Bustamante’s Si Tandang Basio Macunat, 1885, reprinted in 2005
media_credit: Photo from UP Sentro ng Wikang Filipino
text_description: Si Tandang Basio Macunat by Spanish friar Miguel Lucio Bustamante, which attacks liberal ideas, is published. Photo: Book cover of 2005 reprint (UP Sentro ng Wikang Filipino)

media_caption: Isabelo de los Reyes, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Isabelo de los Reyes (in photo) publishes El Folk-lore Filipino, a two-volume, pioneering collection of folklore materials. An English translation will be published in 1994.

media_caption: Scene from Sari and Kiri Dalena’s docudrama Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos, 2014
text_description: Feb: Jose Rizal sends a letter to “the women of Malolos,” which praises them for their desire for education and defines Rizal’s “ideal” woman. Photo: Scene from Sari and Kiri Dalena’s docudrama Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos, 2014 (Photo courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Apolinario Mabini, prime minister of the first Philippine republic
media_credit: Photo from the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines
text_description: Apolinario Mabini writes “El Verdadero Decalogo,” enumerating the values that he thinks Filipinos should possess. (Photo colorized by the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines)

media_caption: Title page of the 1760 edition of the first Tagalog pasyon by Gaspar Aquino de Belen
text_headline: The Mahal na Pasion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola by Gaspar Aquino de Belen is published.
text_description: Gaspar Aquino de Belen publishes the earliest pasyon, a long verse narrative on the Passion of Christ titled Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Cristong Panginoon Natin na Tola, which is set to octosyllabic quintillas. It appears as an addendum to his translation of a Spanish devotional work.

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Elena Gardoce, 1992
text_description: Epic chanter Elena Gardoce is given the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

media_caption: Tomas Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila, originally published in 1610, and reprinted in 2011
text_description: Tomas Pinpin prints Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila, which contains samples of ladino poetry or poems alternating Tagalog lines with Spanish ones. Photo: Book cover of 2011 reprint (UST Publishing House)

media_caption: Title page of Fr Gaspar de San Agustin’s Compendio del Arte de la Lengua Tagala, 1870
article_title: Lit 1703 Compendio del Arte de la Lengua
text_description: Jan 20: Compendio del Arte de la Lengua Tagala by Fray Gaspar de San Agustin records the first statement of literary criticism made by a native: “Magaling, datapoa hindi tola.” (Photo from University of Michigan)

media_caption: 2013 reprint of Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar’s Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala, originally published in 1754
article_title: Lit 1754 Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala
text_description: Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala by Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar is published. It contains samples of early Tagalog poetry, including the tanaga. Photo: Book cover of 2013 reprint (Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino)

media_caption: The Peninsulars by Linda Ty-Casper, 1964
text_description: The British occupation of Manila will inspire the novel The Peninsulars by Linda Ty-Casper, the first of her many historical novels. (Photo from Bookmark, Inc)

media_caption: Vicente Sotto, Poets in the native languages, Cebuano
text_description: “Maming” by Vicente Sotto (in photo), considered the first Cebuano short story, is published in Ang Suga.

media_caption: Si Nena at si Neneng, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Early Tagalog novels by Valeriano Hernandez Peña and Iñigo Ed. Regalado
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
text_description: Continuing the didactic tradition set by Urbana at Feliza, the novel Nena at Neneng by Valeriano Hernandez-Peña is serialized. It will become the first Tagalog novel to be published in book form in 1905.

media_caption: Benjamin, Early Ilonggo novel by Angel Magahum, 1920
media_credit: Photo from National Commission for Culture and the Arts
text_description: The first known Ilonggo novel, Benjamin, Novela con Panuguiron nga Binisaya by Angel Magahum, is published. (Photo: 1920 edition of Benjamin from National Commission for Culture and the Arts)

media_caption: Lidia, Juan Crisostomo C. Soto, 1907, Romantic novel in Kapampangan
media_credit: Photo from Don Honorio Ventura Technological State University- Center for Capampangan Culture and the Arts
text_description: The novel Lidia by Juan Crisostomo Soto, the first prose narrative of its kind in Kapampangan literature, noted for a developed degree of realism, is published.(Photo from Don Honorio Ventura Technological State University Center for Capampangan Culture and the Arts)

media_caption: El Renacimiento, Politically oriented periodical
text_description: The editorial “Aves de Rapiña,” which denounces “a man, who, besides being like the eagle, also has the characteristic of the vulture, the owl, and the vampire,” appears in El Renacimineto. Dean Worcester, Secretary of the Interior, files a libel case against the periodical and eventually wins.

media_caption: Members of the Aklatang Bayan, a Tagalog writers’ group, including Lope K. Santos, Patricio Mariano, Severino Reyes, Carlos Ronquillo, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda, ca 1930
media_credit: Photo from Dictionary of Philippine Biography by E. Arsenio Manuel. Filipiniana Publications, 1955
text_description: Aklatang Bayan, an organization of Tagalog writers, is established in Tondo, with Rosauro Almario as president. (Photo from Dictionary of Philippine Biography by E. Arsenio Manuel, Filipiniana Publications, 1955)

media_caption: Buak nang Ester by Aurelio Tolentino, 1911, Pre-World War II novel written in local language
text_description: Aurelio Tolentino publishes Ing Buac nang Ester, a Kapampangan novel which employs Victorian and gothic elements. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Amado V. Hernandez, a poet in his native language Tagalog
text_description: Ilaw at Panitik, a literary society, is founded in Manila by Buenaventura Medina, Remigio Mat. Castro, and others, with Deogracias Rosario, Jose Corazon de Jesus, and Amado V. Hernandez (in photo) as members.

media_caption: Crisalidas, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, 1914, Books of poetry in Spanish
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
text_description: Crisalidas, by Fernando Ma. Guerrero, the “maestro” by a generation of Filipino writers in Spanish. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)

media_caption: Zoilo M. Galang’s A Child of Sorrow, 1921, made into a movie in the 1930s
media_credit: Photo from Thea Barachina and Abiva Publishing House
text_description: The first Filipino novel in English, A Child of Sorrow by Zoilo Galang, is published. (Photo from Thea Barachina and Abiva Publishing House)

media_caption: Liwayway,1948, The Ramon Roces line of magazines
text_description: Liwayway is founded and will become the most widely read Tagalog magazine. It will serialize many important novels, including Ang Tundo Man May Langit Din, Daluyong, and Canal de la Reina. Photo: A 1948 edition of Liwayway (Liwayway Publications, Inc)

media_caption: Florentino Collantes, left, and Jose Corazon de Jesus, the most famous “kings” of balagtasan, ca 1930
text_description: Apr 6: The first balagtasan, a poetic oratorical joust, is held in Manila; it is between Florentino Collantes and Jose Corazon de Jesus (in photo, left and right, respectively). (Photo from Teodoro Agoncillo Collection)

media_caption: Magdalena Jalandoni, Poets in the native languages, Ilonggo
text_description: The novel Ang Bantay sang Patyo by Magdalena Jalandoni (in photo), known as the “Grand Old Lady of Ilonggo Literature,” is published.

media_caption: The UP Writers’ Club including, seated from left to right, Manuel Arguilla, Federico Mangahas, Salvador P. Lopez, English teacher Robert Conklin, Fernando Leaño, Fidel de Castro, and Vicente del Fierro
media_credit: Photo from Fernandez and Alegre 1984, Cultural Center of the Philippines
text_description: A group of UP students, including Casiano Calalang, Loreto Paras, Arturo Rotor, Paz Latorena, and Jose Garcia Villa, forms the UP Writers’ Club. Its official publication, founded in the same year, is the Literary Apprentice. (Photo from The Writer and His Milieu by Edilberto Alegre and Doreen Fernandez, De La Salle University Press, 1984)

media_caption: 1995 reprint of Jose Corazon de Jesus’s Sa Dakong Silangan, originally published in 1928
text_description: Sa Dakong Silangan by Jose Corazon de Jesus, an allegorical narrative poem denouncing Spanish and, later, American imperialist interests, is published. Photo: Book cover of 1995 reprint (CCP and NCCA)

media_caption: Novel in Spanish during the American period by Antonio M. Abad, 1929, published in English translation in the year 2013
text_description: La Oveja de Nathan by Antonio M. Abad, which critiques the effects of American imperialism, is published. The novel will be reprinted with an English translation in 2013. (Photo from Ayala Foundation, Inc)

media_caption: Kenkoy ni Tony Velasquez, Liwayway, 1929, First comic strip in the Philippines written and illustrated by Antonio Velasquez and published in Liwayway, 1929
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
text_description: The first Kenkoy comic strip is published in Liwayway, popularizing the form in the Philippines. When its writer Romualdo Ramos dies in 1932, Tony Velasquez, its illustrator, takes over until the series ends in 1961. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)

media_caption: Philippine Magazine, Publications which became outlets for writings in English
text_description: Philippine Magazine, edited by A. V. H. Hartendorp, begins to be published. Formerly known as Philippine Teacher (1904), Philippine Education (1906), and Philippine Education Magazine (1926), it will publish many stories that will be considered classics of Philippine literature in English. (Photo from University of Michigan)

media_caption: Arturo Rotor, fictionist in English
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
text_description: Arturo Rotor (in photo) publishes “Zita,” a story showing the influence of Wilbur Daniele Steele, in Philippines Free Press. Along with “Footnote to Youth” by Jose Garcia Villa, it will be named the best short story of the year. Rotor’s stories will be collected in The Wound and the Scar in 1937 and in The Men Who Play God and Other Stories in 1990.

media_caption: Ilaw sa Hilaga by Lazaro Francisco, 1997, Works influenced by motifs from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo
text_description: Lazaro Francisco serializes Bayang Nagpatiwakal, a novel of social criticism after Jose Rizal’s Noli and Fili, in Alitaptap. The novel is revised and is published as Ilaw sa Hilaga in 1947-48. Photo: Book cover of 1997 reprint (University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Hiligaynon (Ilonggo), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: The magazine Ang Bisaya sa Hiligaynon, later renamed Hiligaynon, is founded, with Abe Gonzales as its first editor. Hiligaynon becomes an important outlet of Western Visayas writing. Among the writers it will publish are Ramon Muzones, Conrado Norada, and Magdalena Jalandoni. (Photo from Liwayway Publications)

media_caption: Bannawag (Ilokano), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: The magazine Bannawag is founded and becomes an important main venue for literature in Ilocano. Writers published in Bannawag will include Juan S. P. Hidalgo, Gregorio Laconsay, and Marcelino Foronda. (Photo from Liwayway Publications)

media_caption: Salvador P. Lopez for his essay “Literature and Society”, Winners of the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Awards
text_description: The Philippine Writers League is organized with Federico Mangahas and Salvador P. Lopez (in photo) as president and vice president, respectively. It organizes a writers conference and the Commonwealth Literary Contest, which champions literature with social consciousness against the art for art’s sake philosophy identified with Jose Garcia Villa.

media_caption: Genoveva Edroza-Matute, awarded in 1992, Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Panitikan) awardees
text_description: Genoveva Edroza-Matute (in photo) publishes her first short story, “Walong Taong Gulang,” in Mabuhay Extra, introducing readers to a writer adept in channeling a child’s psyche. Her stories will be collected in Piling Maiikling Kuwento 1939-1992 in 1992.

media_caption: Manuel Arguilla for his short story “How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife,” Winners of the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Awards
article_title: Lit 1940.1 How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife
text_description: "How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife" by Manuel Arguilla (in photo), known for capturing “local color” in his stories, is published.

media_caption: Angela Manalang Gloria, Writers in English, poets
text_description: Angela Manalang-Gloria publishes Poems, arguably the first feminist collection of poems in English. It includes the controversial “Revolt from the Hymen.”

media_caption: Cecilio Apostol, Notable Filipino writers in Spanish
text_description: Pentelicas by Cecilio Apostol is published.

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, 1982, National Artists for Literature
text_description: For “his observations and forecasts of Far Eastern developments during a tour of the trouble centers from Hong Kong to Batavia,” Carlos P. Romulo receives the Pulitzer Prize for Correspondence.

media_caption: Have Come, Am Here by Jose Garcia Villa, Jose Garcia Villa’s books published in the United States
media_credit: Photo from New Directions and Viking Press
text_description: Have Come, Am Here by Jose Garcia Villa is published in New York, making him a celebrity in the American literary scene and cementing his reputation in the Philippines. He is nominated for the Pulitzer Prize but loses to Robert Frost. (Photo from New Directions and Viking Press)

media_caption: Cuentos De Juana, Adelina Gurrea, 1943, Published folk tale
text_description: Adelina Gurrea publishes Cuentos de Juana, a collection of short stories set in a Negros sugar plantation at the turn of the 20th century and featuring creatures from native folklore in Madrid. (Photo from Imprenta de Prensa Española)

media_caption: Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943, Compilation of winning short stories in Tagalog during the Japanese Occupation
text_description: Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943 is published. It collects the entries to a contest sponsored by the Manila Sinbun-sya, the cultural arm of the Japanese government in the Philippines, whose aim is to eradicate traces of Western culture in the country. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Alejandro G. Abadilla’s Parnasong Tagalog, one of the notable surveys and studies of Philippine literature in Filipino during the 1950s
media_credit: Photo from Limbagan ng Dalubhasaang Epifanio de los Santos
text_description: A landmark anthology of Tagalog poetry, Parnasong Tagalog, edited by Alejandro G. Abadilla, is published. (Photo from Limbagan ng Dalubhasaang Epifanio de los Santos)

media_caption: Mga Piling Akda ng Kadipan, 1965, a publication of one of the key literary groups in the 1950s
text_description: Oct 22: KADIPAN (Kapisanang Aklat, Diwa, at Panitik), which will hold literary contests for work published in school papers, is established by students of Manuel L. Quezon Educational Institution (later University). Photo: Book cover of Mga Piling Akda ng Kadipan, 1965 (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Ravens in Love, 2002, a publication of one of the key literary groups in the 1950s
text_description: A group of English writers from UP including Hilario Francia, S. V. Epistola, Virginia Moreno, and Alejandrino Hufana, forms the Ravens, with N. V. M. Gonzalez as mentor. Photo: Book cover of Ravens In Love, an anthology of works by Ravens members, 2002 (Photo from Anvil Publishing Inc)

media_caption: Prose and Poems by Nick Joaquin, 1952, Philippine literature in English
article_title: Lit 1952 Prose and Poems of Joaquin
text_description: The short stories, poems, and a novella of Nick Joaquin are published in Prose and Poems, portraying the Filipino as a creature caught between conflicting historical forces. Joaquin’s later stories will be collected in Tropical Gothic, 1972. (Photo from Graphic House)

media_caption: Ako'y Isang Tinig by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, 1952, Collection of literary works by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, 1952
text_description: One of the earliest single-author collections of Tagalog short stories, Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s Ako’y Isang Tinig, is published. (Photo from UP Press)

media_caption: Amador Daguio, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: Amador Daguio (in photo) makes an English translation of the Ifugao epic Hudhud hi Aliguyon, as chanted by Hinayup Bantayan. It will be published in Epics of the Philippines in 1983.

media_caption: A Season of Grace by N.V.M. Gonzalez, 1956, Novel in English
text_description: Aug 6: N. V. M. Gonzalez serializes A Season of Grace, notable for being told from the point of view of a kaingero and for catching the rhythm of the local dialect in English, in Weekly Women’s Magazine. (Photo from Benipayo Press)

media_caption: You Lovely People by Bienvenido N. Santos, 1955, Collection of modern short stories in English
text_description: You Lovely People by Bienvenido Santos, chronicling the condition of the Filipino exile in America, is published; it includes his most well-known story “Scent of Apples.” (Photo from Benipayo Press)

media_caption: Lope K. Santos, a poet in his native language Tagalog
article_title: Lit 1955.2 Ang Apat na Himagsik ni Balagtas
text_description: Lope K. Santos’s landmark study Ang Apat na Himagsik ni Balagtas, which reads Florante at Laura as a political text critical of the Spanish colonial regime, is published.

media_caption: Magnificence and other stories, Estrella D. Alfon, 1962, Philippine literature in English
article_title: Lit 1955.4 A Fairy Tale for the City
text_description: Aug 21: “A Fairy Tale for the City” by Estrella Alfon is published in This Week. Alfon is sued for obscenity, and the court bans the reprinting of the story. Her other stories will be collected in Magnificence and Other Stories in 1960.

media_caption: Perfil de Cresta by Manuel Bernabe, 1957, Posthumous collection of works in Spanish
text_description: The Spanish poems of Manuel Bernabe, the “king of balagtasan in Spanish,” are collected in Perfil de Cresta. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila)

media_caption: Mga Ibong Mandaragit by Amado V. Hernandez, 1959, Social realist novel
text_description: Liwayway begins serialization of Mga Ibong Mandaragit by Amado V. Hernandez, noted for its lucid analysis of the nature of class conflict in city and country.

media_caption: Gregorio Brillantes, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: The Distance to Andromeda and Other Stories by Gregorio Brillantes (in photo) is published. It includes “Faith, Love, Time and Doctor Lazaro,” establishing him as a “Catholic writer.”

media_caption: The Woman Who Had Two Navels by Nick Joaquin, 1961, Novel in English
media_credit: Photo from Philippine Center of PEN International
article_title: Lit 1961 The Woman Who Had Two Navels
text_description: Nick Joaquin’s The Woman Who Had Two Navels, which explores the question of national identity and the ambiguity of good and evil, is published. (Photo from Philippine Center of PEN International)

media_caption: Silliman National Writers’ Workshop, 1966
text_description: Patterned after the Iowa Writers Workshop, the inaugural Silliman Writers Workshop, founded by Edith and Edilberto Tiempo, is held in Dumaguete City. Similar workshops will be established in the University of the Philippines, the Ateneo de Manila University, and other institutions. (Photo from Silliman University)

media_caption: Jose Garcia Villa, poet in English
text_description: Alberto S. Florentino launches the Peso Books, which, priced at one peso a copy, seeks to popularize Philippine literature, starting with Poems 55 by Jose Garcia Villa (in photo). (Photo from CCP Collection)

media_caption: The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker by Gilda Cordero-Fernando, 1962
article_title: Lit 1962.5 The Butcher, The Baker, The Candlestick Maker
text_description: The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker by Gilda Cordero-Fernando is published, offering portraits of the middle class Filipino woman. Cordero-Fernando will venture into publishing books on national identity and heritage. (Photo from Bookmark, Inc)

media_caption: Tuwaang Atteds a Wedding, E. Arsenio Manuel, 1975, Text of Philippine epics in book form
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
article_title: Lit 1963.2 A Survey of Philippine Epics
text_description: E. Arsenio Manuel’s pioneering “A Survey of Philippine Epics” is published in Asian Folklore Studies. Manuel’s transcriptions and studies of the Ilianon and the Manobo epics result in such publication as The Maiden of the Buhong Sky, 1958; Agyu,1969; and Tuwaang Attends a Wedding, 1975. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Leonard Casper’s The Wounded Diamond, a literary criticism in English that emerged in the 1960s
text_description: The Wounded Diamond: Studies in Modern Philippine Literature by Leonard Casper, a collection of critical essays that apply the New Criticism to the works of 29 Filipino writers, is published. (Photo from Bookmark, Inc)

media_caption: Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway by Rogelio Sicat, 1965, Work influenced by motifs from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Sep 6: Liwayway begins the serialization of Dugo sa Bukang Liwayway by Rogelio Sicat, aka Rogelio Sikat, which takes off from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo. It will be reprinted as a book in 1989. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
text_description: Edith Tiempo’s first poetry collection, The Tracks of Babylon and Other Poems, is published.

media_caption: Bembol Roco and Hilda Koronel in Lino Brocka’s Maynila: Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, 1975, a film adaptation of Edgardo M. Reyes’s novel, Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag
article_title: Lit 1967 Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag
text_description: Nov 13: Liwayway begins serialization of Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag by Edgardo Reyes, notable for its dark portrayal of urban life. Photo: Bembol Roco in Maynila: Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, 1975, Lino Brocka's film adaptation of Reyes's novel (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Antonio Manuud’s Brown Heritage, a literary criticism in English that emerged in the 1960s
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Brown Heritage: Essays on Philippine Cultural Tradition and Literature, a collection of pioneering studies on a broad range of topics in Philippine culture, the first of its kind, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Kerima Polotan, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: Stories: A Collection by Kerima Polotan (in photo) is published. It includes “The Sounds of Sunday,” winner of the Asia Magazine literary prize and the germ of her novel The Hand of the Enemy, 1962.

media_caption: Bituen Ti Rosales by Juan S.P. Hidalgo, Jr., 1969, collection of fiction written in Ilocano
article_title: Lit 1969.1 Bituen ti Rosales ken Dadduma
text_description: Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr publishes a collection of Ilocano short stories, Bituen ti Rosales ken Dadduma Pay a Sarita. (Photo from Ilokano Publishing House)

media_caption: Clodualdo del Mundo’s Mula Sa Parolang Ginto, one of the notable surveys and studies of Philippine literature in Filipino during the 1960s
text_description: Mula sa Parolang Ginto by Clodualdo L. del Mundo, one of the first compilations of literary criticism in Tagalog, is published. (Photo from Liwayway Publications)

media_caption: Kung Wala na ang Tag-araw, Ano Ngayon, Ricky? By Rosario De Guzman-Lingat, A work of fiction using psychological realism
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
article_title: Lit 1970.1 Kung Wala na ang Tag-Araw
text_description: Rosario de Guzman Lingat publishes her first novel, Kung Wala na ang Tag-araw, a complex psychological study of an adulterous man. Photo: Book cover of 2011 reprint (Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Amado V. Hernandez, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1973
text_description: Amado V. Hernandez is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa by Dominador Mirasol, 1975, Social realist literature
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Sagisag begins serialization of Dominador Mirasol’s Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa, notable for its lucid depiction of the continuing struggles of Filipino peasants. Photo: Book cover of 1998 edition (University of the Philippines Press Press)

media_caption: Nick Joaquin, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1976
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection and Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: Nick Joaquin is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Davao Harvest, Ricardo M. de Ungria, Tita Lacambra Ayala, 2008, Regional literature of the new millennium
media_credit: National Commission for Culture and the Arts
text_description: Davao Harvest, which collects literary works and visual art by writers and artists in and from Davao, is published. Photo: Book cover of 2008 edition (NCCA)

media_caption: Bikols of the Philippines, 1983, Scholarship on regional literary materials
text_description: Bikols of the Philippines by Maria Lilia F. Realubit is published.

media_caption: Balagtasismo Versus Modernismo, Virgilio S. Almario, 1984, Work of literary history
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Balagtasismo versus Modernismo, Virgilio Almario’s study of two schools of Tagalog poetry, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera’s Tagalog Poetry 1570-1898, 2001, a survey of Tagalog poetry during the Spanish colonial period
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Tagalog Poetry, 1570-1898 by Bienvenido Lumbera, an expansive and pioneering critical text on the development of Tagalog poetry, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano by Marcel M. Navarra, 1986, Regional collection of fiction
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
article_title: Lit 1986.2 Navarra's Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano
text_description: Twelve short stories of Cebuano writer Marcel Navarra published between 1930 and 1955 are collected in Marcel Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano, an attempt by three university presses to reprint and translate classic Philippine literary works written in the different Philippine languages. (UP Press)

media_caption: Volume Five of the Maranao Darangen, published in 1988
text_description: The first three volumes of Sr. Maria Delia Coronel’s translation of Darangen, the epic of the Maranao, is published. (Photo from Mindanao State University)

media_caption: Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, Alfred A. Yuson, 1988, Work of metafiction
text_description: “Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café” by Alfred Yuson wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel. It will be published in 1988. (Photo from Adriana Printing Co, Inc)

media_caption: Ricardo Lee
article_title: Lit 1988.1 Si Tatang at ang Himala ng Ating Panahon
text_description: Ricardo Lee gathers his best writing in several genres, including screenplay, short story, essay, feature article, and interview, in Si Tatang at ang Himala ng Ating Panahon.

media_caption: Kurditan: Mga Kuwentong Iluko, edited by Reynaldo A. Duque, Jose A. Bragado, and Linda T. Lingbaoan,1988, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
text_description: The first anthology of translations in Filipino of Ilocano stories, Kurditan: Mga Kwentong Iluko, is published, containing 30 short stories. (Photo from GUMIL Filipinas)

media_caption: State of War by Ninotchka Rosca, 1988, Socially oriented work in English
text_description: Ninotchka Rosca publishes the magic realist novel A State of War, which covers 400 years of Philippine history. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Rolando Tinio's Kristal Na Uniberso
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila Office of Research and Publications
text_description: Rolando Tinio publishes Kristal na Uniberso, which marks the poet’s return to the tradition of Philippine romantic poetry while still following the “bagay” school. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila Office of Research and Publications)

media_caption: STR, Mga Tula ng Digmaang Bayan sa Pilipinas, Anthology of activist literature during the martial law era
text_description: STR, mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas brings to the surface underground poetry from various sectors and regions. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Men of the East, Charlson Ong, 1999, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
article_title: Lit 1990 Men of the East and Other Stories
text_description: Charlson Ong publishes Men of the East and Other Stories, an examination of the Chinese-Filipino experience. (Photo from Kalikasan Press)

media_caption: Bamboo in the Wind by Azucena Grajo Uranza, 1990, Realist novel in English
text_description: “Bamboo in the Wind” by Azucena Grajo Uranza wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel. It is published in the same year. (Photo from Vera-Reyes Inc)

media_caption: Kudaman, Edgar B. Maranan, Regional literature reprinted with translation in Filipino
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: A translation by Edgardo B. Maranan and Nicole Revel-Macdonald of the Palawan epic Kudaman, as chanted by Usuy, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Cubao 1980 at iba pang mga katha by Tony Perez, 1992, Gay literature in the 1990s
text_description: Cubao 1980, the first in Tony Perez’s Cubao series, notable for its depiction of the lives of gay men, is published. (Photo from Cacho Publishing House)

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera, awarded National Artist for literature in 2006
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Bienvenido Lumbera’s Likhang Dila, Likhang Diwa, which collects the author’s poems written between 1956 and 1992, is published.

media_caption: Killing time in a Warm Place by Jose Y. Dalisay, Jr., 1992, Realist novel in English
article_title: Lit 1993.1 Killing Time in a Warm Place
text_description: <>“Killing Time in a Warm Place” by Jose Dalisay and “Subanons” by Antonio Enriquez share the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel in English. The novels will be published in 1992 and 1999, respectively. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Ladlad, 1994, an anthology of gay literature edited by J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto
text_description: The first of the Ladlad anthologies, which gather together contemporary gay literature, is published, with J. Neil Garcia and Danton Remoto as editors.

media_caption: Penmanship, Jose Dalisay Jr., 1995, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
text_description: Jose Dalisay’s Penmanship and Other Stories, a showcase of the author’s mastery of the genre, is published. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Carlos Quirino, awarded National Artist for literature in 1997
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Carlos Quirino (1910-99), author of a biography of Rizal, The Great Malayan, is declared National Artist for his historical writings.

media_caption: Levi Celerio, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1997
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection and Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: Levi Celerio (1910-2002) is declared National Artist in Music and Literature.

media_caption: N. V. M. Gonzalez, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1997
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection and Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: N. V. M. Gonzalez is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Jose Rey Munsayac’s Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum, first place in the Philippine Centennial Literary Prize in the Filipino novel category
text_description: The winners of the Centennial Literary Contest, which will later be published by the University of the Philippines Press, include “Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum” by Jose Reyes Munsayac and “Etsa-Puwera” by Jun Cruz Reyes (novel in Filipino), and “My Sad Republic” by Eric Gamalinda (novel in English). (Photo from UP Press)

media_caption: Muog: Ang Naratibo ng Kanayunan sa Matagalang Digmaang Bayan sa Pilipinas, UP Press, Anthology of activist literature during the martial law era
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Muog, a multi-language anthology of narratives by cadres and other figures on the protracted armed communist struggle in the countryside, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Sa Labas ng Parlor, Honorio Bartolome de Dios, 1998, Gay literature in the 1990s
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s Sa Labas ng Parlor, an account of the Filipino gay experience with a radical bent, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Smaller and smaller circles, F.H. Batacan, 2007 reprint
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Smaller and Smaller Circles” by Ma. Felisa H. Batacan wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be published nationally in 2002; revised and published in the United States in 2015. It will be made into a film in 2017. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Members of the Davao Writers’ Guild
text_description: May: The Davao Writers Guild is organized, with Don Pagusara as its first president.

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Edith L. Tiempo is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Caroline Hau, Chinese-Filipino writer
text_description: Intsik: An Anthology of Chinese-Filipino Writing, edited by Caroline Hau (in photo), is published. It will be translated into Chinese in 2003. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University)

media_caption: Sarilaysay: Tinig ng 20 Babae sa Sariling Danas Bilang Manunulat, 2000
text_description: Rosario Torres-Yu’s Sarilaysay, an inquiry into the consciousness of woman writers via storytelling sessions with 20 writers, is published. It will be followed in 2004 by a companion volume of interviews with male writers. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: F. Landa Jocano, right, recording Hugan-an chanting the Hinilawod in the mountains of Central Panay. ca 1955
media_credit: Photo from Hinilawod: Adventures of Humadapnon [Tarangban I], PUNLAD Research House, 2000
text_description: A translation by F. Landa Jocano of the Panay epic Hinilawod, as chanted by Ulang Uding in 1964, is published. Photo: F. Landa Jocano, right, recording Hugan-an chanting the Hinilawod in the mountains of Central Panay, ca 1955 (Photo from Hinilawod: Adventures of Humadapnon [Tarangban I], PUNLAD Research House, 2000)

media_caption: The Trilogy of Saint Lazarus by Cirilo F. Bautista, Philippine poetry in English
media_credit: Photo from De La Salle University Press
article_title: Lit 2001 The Trilogy of Saint Lazarus
text_description: Cirilo Bautista’s epic poem The Trilogy of Saint Lazarus, which maps out the country’s history from precolonial times to after the EDSA Revolt, is published. (Photo from De La Salle University Press)

media_caption: F. Sionil Jose, awarded National Artist for literature in 2001
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: F. Sionil Jose is declared National Artist.

media_caption: The Sky Over Dimas, Vicente Garcia Groyon, 2003, Novel with social and historical themes
text_description: “The Sky over Dimas” by Vicente Garcia Groyon wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be published in 2003. (Photo from De La Salle University Press)

media_caption: The Firewalkers, Erwin E. Castillo, 1992, Work of metafiction
text_description: Erwin Castillo’s novel Firewalkers, a whirlwind tour of Philippine history through the mythical Cavite town Lakambaga, is published. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Virgilio S. Almario, awarded National Artist for literature in 2003
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Virgilio S. Almario is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Mga Tulang tulala, Kristian Sendon Cordero, 2004, Filipino poetry in Bikol
media_credit: Photo from Photo from Goldprint Publishing House
text_description: Kristian Cordero’s Mga Tulang Tulala, a collection of poems in Filipino, Bicol, and Rinconada, is published. (Photo from Goldprint Publishing House)

media_caption: Salamanca, Dean Francis Alfar, 2006, Work of metafiction
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)
text_description: “Salamanca” by Dean Francis Alfar wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be published in 2007. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera, awarded National Artist for literature in 2006
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Bienvenido Lumbera is declared National Artist.

media_caption: At the 2012 Talaang Ginto Gawad Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino sa Tula, with Bicol-based poet Jose Jason Chancoco, fourth from left, receiving his prize
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Jose Jason L. Chancoco
text_description: Pagsasatubuanan: Poetikang Bikolnon by Jason Chancoco, the first book-length study of the rawitdawit or Bikol poetry, is published.

media_caption: Ilustrado by Miguel Syjuco, Book of fiction with allegorical themes
text_description: “Ilustrado” by Miguel Syjuco wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will win the Man Asian Literary Prize and be published in 2010. (Photo from Penguin Random House Canada)

media_caption: Lazaro Francisco, awarded National Artist for literature in 2009
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
text_description: Lazaro Francisco is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Cirilo F. Bautista, awarded National Artist for literature in 2014
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University
article_title: Lit 2014 Cirilo F. Bautista, National Artist
text_description: Cirilo F. Bautista is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Doctrina Christiana en la Lengua Española y Tagala, 1593
text_description: The Dominicans publish Doctrina Christiana en la Lengua Española y Tagala, the first book to be printed in the Philippines, by xylography.

media_caption: Collection of socially committed poetry in Tagalog by Lamberto E. Antonio, 1980
text_description: Hagkis ng Talahib, the first poetry collection of Lamberto Antonio, is published. (Photo from Aklat Peskador)

media_caption: Mga Agos sa Disyerto
media_credit: Book cover courtesy of C&E Publishing, Inc
text_description: Mga Agos sa Disyerto, containing the stories of Edgardo M. Reyes, Rogelio R. Sicat, Efren Abueg, Eduardo Bautista Reyes, and Rogelio Ordoñez, is published, ushering in modernism in the Tagalog short story. Photo: Book cover of 1993 edition (C & E Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat
text_description: Muling Pagsilang begins serialization of Banaag at Sikat by Lope K. Santos, widely considered as the first Tagalog novel imbued with an emergent socialist consciousness and working class ideology. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: An edition of Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang
article_title: Lit 1963 Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang
text_description: The two-volume Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang is published. It collects the best and most popular of the Lola Basyang stories originally published in Liwayway. (Photo from Lebby P. Bermudez)

media_caption: Cover of Bisaya
text_description: The magazine Bisaya is founded, with Vicente Padriga as editor. It becomes an outlet for Cebuano literature. Among its contributors will be Marcel Navarra, Godofredo Roperos, Vicente Rama, and Maria Kabigon. (Photo from Cebuano Studies Center)

media_caption: Founding members of the Ilocano writers’ group GUMIL-Filipinas
text_description: Oct 19: Gumil Filipinas is formally organized, four years after the formation of Gumil Ilocos Sur, the first provincial organization of Ilocano writers.
